data.text: Bike Touring with a Titanium Frame Bicycle
Who is riding a titanium frame? If so, is it worth the cost? Lynskey is having a really good sale right now and it's tempting me!
Kinesis Tripster ATR Ti with Enve carbon fork. Lovely and supple ride, you know it makes sense.
data.author: Shaun Phillips

data.text: I have a Ti road bike, and I love it. Keep in mind Lynskey is always having a "sale", and that when you add all of the "extras" that are typically standard with other brands, it doesn't end up being that much of a deal. Still, good bikes and made in US.
data.author: Benjamin Arians

data.text: The trick is to sign up, put the frame in your cart and then sign out and wait. They will email you all kinds of discounts.
data.author: John Hinderliter

data.text: I was only going to buy the frame/fork and do my own build. The only extra I might consider would be the titanium seatpost. The cost of the frame I'm considering is about the same as a carbon one that I have had my eye on.
data.author: Greg Jameson

data.text: , Yep!
data.author: Mondo Mike

data.text: Lynskeys are wonderful bikes. Carbon fork and rock and roll. Had a lynskey road bike 15yrs ago shoulda never sold.
data.author: Chatham Sinclair

data.text: I'm on my third ti bike. Rides like nothing else. The Lynskey frames are phenomenal.
data.author: John Hinderliter

data.text: Get the Bike😎😎😎
data.author: Buford Keith Harrell

data.text: I want a full ti no carbon. Dream gravel is titanium fork included
data.author: Harley Grey

data.text: I’m on a Lynskey road bike and love it!
data.author: Chad Thomas
Darren Lavallee

data.text: Here is a Titanium 650B Mosiac from Black Oak Velo. Good on dirt, trails, and pavement. One bike is all you need.
data.author: Darren Lavallee

data.text: Snatch one if is good deal, I really want one it make easier take flights with one as is very sturdy and lighter than steel.
data.author: Carlo Del Mazo
Dan Cable

data.text: I love my Thomson piedmont
data.author: Lonnie J Young

data.text: Love my T-Lab X3
data.author: Vincent Armstrong

data.text: Yes. Love it.
data.author: Xaver von Treyer

data.text: Love Ti! Raced Steamboat on it, and yes, it’s worth the extra few $$. You don’t need to baby as much as carbon and one of my most favorite bikes I’ve owned.
data.author: David Bryant

data.text: wait, I'm supposed to baby my carbon frames...didn't get that memo.
data.author: Danny Baggett

data.text: LOL - I have an all black carbon bike also, shows every scratch, rub mark, and fingerprint. And I try to baby it 😉
data.author: David Bryant

data.text: I have scratches on mine. I have stickers to cover the bad ones...buy so far those are just on the aluminum frame. 🙃
data.author: Danny Baggett

data.text: Do not waste your with anything else. Titanium all the way.
data.author: Hector Ramon Rodrigo

data.text: No go carbon
data.author: John Trotter

data.text: I have a carbon road bike and a carbon gravel bike. Have you tried titanium?
data.author: Greg Jameson

data.text: yes a Moots nowhere near as good as carbon. Maybe TI alloy was better than carbon 10 years ago but not now. Carbon can be stiff in the right areas and compliant in the right areas. Most TI alloy bikes have to use carbon bars, forks and seat posts to make them more comfortable and lighter. TI alloy is very attractive but from a performance perspective Apples to Apples its not there anymore.
data.author: John Trotter

data.text: all that said carbon feels dead. I’ve now converted all disciplines to TI. The ride quality is lively. I just couldn’t get into the carbon feel plus I snapped two carbon frames over the years. That along scares me.
data.author: Bob Benson

data.text: depends on the level of carbon you are riding. Its hard to imagine snapping carbon from just riding. Sounds like carbon isn’t your thing.
data.author: John Trotter

data.text: maybe….bikes were reputable brands at 8-10k fully built. I’m 6’7” & 230 but we’ll within their weight limits. 🤷🏻‍♂️
data.author: Bob Benson

data.text:
Before I got my carbon gravel frame, I rode my Seven Axiom "road" frame on every type of surface I could find. Rode a Merlin Extralight before that. Am now looking into selling my carbon gravel bike and building a Waltly. Also, this is the best deal on a Ti complete gravel bike I've found @ $2,600.https://www.framedbikes.com/products/basswood-titanium-gravel-bike-2021?gclid=CjwKCAjw6fyXBhBgEiwAhhiZsl8EUmbQ8OnGy9EoXgDPMbcJj81XclRk7WFcCKwypAmb2BPYdOUEcxoCNh4QAvD_BwE
Basswood Titanium Gravel Bike w/ Carbon Wheels
framedbikes.com
data.author: Jim Ryan

data.text: Modern high end steel is so good that I can’t tell the difference in ride quality between my moots and steel road bikes. I used to be all in on ti, but I don’t think the price difference is worth it anymore.
data.author: Eric von Eckartsberg

data.text: pretty close. Steel is a hair heavier and isn’t as pretty though.
data.author: Tom Kucklick

data.text:
Sometimes. Ti requires more material, so depending on the design and materials, may not make a difference in the end. https://www.renehersecycles.com/myth-2-titanium-is-lighter-than-steel/
Myths Debunked: Titanium is Lighter than Steel, but… – Rene Herse Cycles
renehersecycles.com
data.author: Eric von Eckartsberg

data.text: perhaps. I switched from a high end steel to ti and weighed both frames during the build. In my experience it holds. You results may vary.
data.author: Tom Kucklick

data.text: Yes indeed, we'll worth the $! I have a gr-300 got and extra wheel set, love mine. The comfort is unbelievable, just buy it,thank me later
data.author: Mark Lantrip

data.text: Just ordered a Smokestone Mr Harry. Can't wait 😍
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: Yep 👍
data.author: Ted-Shauna Kiefer Gould

data.text: I love mine (custom geometry Merlin Sandstone) but I also have carbon and aluminum bikes I love…
data.author: Steve Heintzelman

data.text: I rode Litespeed Ultimate for 25 years. Finally thought to upgrade. Bought the Litespeed to replace a cracked Trek OVLV that Trek could not entirely fix. Now on Pro GR I ride most days. All rounder. Sold 3 bikes to build it one a Tarmac. Love SRAM eTap. I9 I35 wheels holding up well after what 5-10 years use? Retired so do not keep track of time like I used to. Thought I needed tougher wheels for gravel but think that might be unnecessary.
data.author: Rich Roberts

data.text: I loved mine so much I bought a second that lives down south.
data.author: Stacey Nieder

data.text: I love my Ti bike for it’s durability but it can’t touch my carbon bike for comfort or weight.
data.author: Bill Maidment

data.text: would say Ti is similar to aluminum, when comparing the "feel" to say, carbon?
data.author: Jim D'Iorio

data.text: no Ti is much more supple than aluminum but may depend on welding and frame design…my Moots is a primo plush frame
data.author: Stephen Jones

data.text: no. Nothing like aluminum. I’ve got a specialized Aethos, it’s in a comfort league of its own.
data.author: Bill Maidment

data.text: , it’s not WHICH material is used but HOW the material is used. Any frame material can be made to perform as the builder wants. There will just be compromises in weight, durability, cost… In production bikes ride quality for a given material can vary widely.
data.author: Shiggy Don Person

data.text: Riding a Moots, Baxter. The frame is their answer for a Tour Divide race bike set-up. Love it, but I don't believe they are making them anymore.
data.author: Andrew Green

data.text: Hi . I got a Baxter a few months ago and am looking for a rear rack for it. What rack do you have on yours?
data.author: Scott Hood

data.text:
it looks like an Axiom or similar: https://www.axiomgear.com/products/racks/streamliner-racks/streamliner-29er-dlx/
Streamliner 29er DLX - Streamliner Racks - Axiom Racks - Products - Axiom Cycling Gear
axiomgear.com
data.author: Jared Carson

data.text: Hey Scott. I had mine built with all the bikepacking mounts for a rear rack, has worked out great. I believe it's an axiom rack, nothing flashy but simple to mount.
data.author: Andrew Green

data.text: Just saw this. Correct it is an Axiom, pleased with it.
data.author: Andrew Green

data.text: Thanks! Just saw this. I made the mistake of not building mine with mounts. The axiom comes with QR feet instead of thru axle, so don't think this will work for me. But thank you for the info. Looks like a perfect rack since I have a set of the mini panniers for another bike.
data.author: Scott Hood

data.text: I have a litespeed hard tail since ‘04. They are beautifully made, durable, and ride really well. Would be ideal for a gravel bike.
data.author: Carl Weston

data.text: I have a GR300 internally routed. I need (want) a road bike and I almost ordered it but they do not have Shimano Ultegra mechanical groupset. Been looking for past few weeks. I would settle for 105 but no Shimano just SRAM.
data.author: Devinder Singh Bahia

data.text: I took advantage of Lynskey’s 20% discount in 2020. Enough of a savings that I splurged on GRX 810 mechanical (pretty new at the time), plus upgraded custom IndustryNine wheels, and anodized bits. Zero percent financing/12 months made the buy even easier to digest. Skipped the ti stem and seatpost because I thought I would change up the touch points and didn’t want to spend on something I might swap anyway. In the end, I love this bike and it’s my favorite long-miler.
data.author: Jerome Paterno

data.text: I have 8 bikes, 7 are ti. I will convert the last one over eventually...my Lynskey cross/gravel bike has more Strava miles than the rest combined
data.author: Bill Lennox

data.text: Did the Dirty Kansa on a carbon frame in the day. Moved to Ti last year and have only ridden the carbon bike a few time since and mostly on the road. I prefer the Ti frame (GR300). It's always a personal thing but I'm going Ti going forward for my road frame as well. As for the sales, it's been said above that it just gets you a few free options. That's accurate. Their bikes are worth the money and the wait. Not to mention the high resale value should it not work out for your preferences.
data.author: David Lowe

data.text: what was your reasoning with the mid race switch, and why are you sticking with it moving forward?
data.author: Kevin Gorchinski

data.text: Sorry if I wasn't clear. I used carbon up until last year not mid race. Staying with Ti going forward
data.author: David Lowe

data.text: I have one and I loves it, Precious.
data.author: Tom Kucklick
Tom Kucklick

data.text: My GR250 has been solid and true. I think it’s not about pure comfort as that is very much how the material is used. But that said, Ti does have a nice damped feel to buzz and shock. And it is pretty darn tough too. The geo of the GR series is long and low as well but not extreme in any of those ways. It’s a very solid all rounder. Not spectacular in any way but not bad either.
data.author: Michael Troy

data.text: Went from carbon to TI. Will never go back for a gravel bike.
data.author: Kris Kasprzyk

data.text: I’ve had 3, two MTB hard tails and one cyclocross bike, all good. They offer a steel frame ride, but lighter, stronger and no rust.
data.author: Rick Kile

data.text: stinger?
data.author: Jeff Foster

data.text: - oops. stronger.
data.author: Rick Kile

data.text: lol I thought I was missing out on some rocket speed device.
data.author: Jeff Foster

data.text: whats cyclecross mean please?
data.author: Mak Isehd

data.text: it’s a sport that is very popular in Europe, especially the Netherlands and Belgium. ( drop bar bikes with tyres to match the off road conditions)
data.author: David Riley

data.text: When I started riding titanium I got rid of everything else.
data.author: Brent Davis

data.text: I absolutely love my Lynskey gravel bike. Message Jordan at Lynskey, they will make it worth it!
data.author: Cody Clark

data.text: Buy the bike!
data.author: Karen Williams

data.text: As mentioned earlier, subscribe to Lynskey’s email offers and then build a bike and put it in your cart a few times. I nearly bought my GR300 at 20% off, and then they emailed me a 35% off coupon valid for 48 hours so I jumped at it. That was March 2020, just days before the pandemic began and the bike component shortage followed. So, I’d be very surprised if they offer a discount that big again, at least until parts are readily available again. And I absolutely love the bike BTW.
data.author: Jason Wold

data.text: I have a Planet X tempest - love titanium - great ride quality and looks amazing
data.author: Nic George

data.text: Do it.
data.author: Thomas T Hodges

data.text: If I could afford it again I’d buy stainless steel.
data.author: Bill Maidment

data.text: If you have the budget get the high quailty steel one, stiffer and lighter
data.author: Chung Yeung

data.text: 100% recommend. I ride a No. 22 Aurora Ti bike, and after spending years on all sorts of rides (carbon, steel, alloy) across the spectrum of price-points, my Ti set-up is the bike I reach for over and over.
data.author: Adam Fulton

data.text: Nice rig
data.author: Bill Maidment

data.text: thank you! I absolutely love it. Couldn’t be happier with how the build turned out 🥳
data.author: Adam Fulton

data.text: I grew up a few miles from it was built. I visited the shop a few years ago. Great people building great bikes.
data.author: Bill Maidment

data.text: Saving my pennies to one day get a Firefly Bikes custom Ti gravel/adventure bike made!
data.author: Chris Bussiere

data.text: Place your order now and it'll be ready when you've got your pennies saved up.
data.author: Bill Maidment

data.text: Yes, 100%
data.author: Norman White

data.text: A great experience can be had riding gravel on any frame material. I like Ti because on our rides there are many obvious and loud gravel, rock, and stick frame strikes. Some chain slap too. None of that bothers me because the frame is immune to damage from those insults. Frame is a Moots Routt 45. All respect to the more expensive and lighter Routt RSL, but I prefer the 45 bc its tube walls are thicker. Doesn’t hurt that the frame’s geometry is spot on in general and for me bc learned from decades of fit experience on other bikes. It’s not the lightest or fastest bike, but is supremely confident in all situations. I would and do ride it anywhere anytime.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: Thanks to you guy... I want a titanium bicycle 😭
data.author: Jose Ruben Mercado
Cat Fish

data.text: Titanium is strong, super long stress life and good ride quality. If you are looking for a bike that will last a long time as you don't buy a bike every few years, it's the way to go.
data.author: Seanman Ellis

data.text: I have a Planet-X tempest in titanium. Absolutely love it, I always wanted a ti bike and this was a bargain
data.author: Alan Hannah

data.text: Yes, yes, yes. I've owned a Lynsky GR260 for 4 years and it's my favorite!
data.author: Peggy O'Neil

data.text: I have the gravel lynskey buy it. This is my favorite bike I have 4 road bikes. It is smooth and comfortable but not the lightest
data.author: Greg Barger

data.text: I have a Lynskey Ti ,rock solid but you better have a good mechanic to build it up right for you.
data.author: Richard Wagner

data.text: I have a Niner ROS, Rocky Mountain full suspension and a Marin (built by Lynskey) single speed Titanium. I’v only ridden the Ti in the past year. There’s nothing like riding a titanium frame.
data.author: David Cruz

data.text: I'm seriously considering a Moots
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: Bought a GR300 this year to replace a (excellent) 2019 Diverge Expert. I like it much better. The Ti dampens the ride a ton while still feeling really efficient. Only downside is that it's about a pound heavier. I still have the Diverge but have only ridden it once since I got the Lynskey.
data.author: Seth Schmautz

data.text: I’ve recently bought a ti Tripster… it’s a lovely bike , but being brutally honest it’s no better than the aluminium G2 that it replaced… does look nice though
data.author: David Riley

data.text: Ti‘s advantages are the less heavy than steel, rustfree and bulletproofed. A roadbike is carbon a good choice. A gravelbike where i put bags on and where the possibility of crashs are higher i prefer ti.
data.author: Mike Wachter

data.text: But if costs are a point, take a steel frame.
data.author: Mike Wachter

data.text: Absolutely LOVE my Lynskey! Jump in and get one !
data.author: David Schwartz

data.text: I do. I ride a Curve Belgie and I love it! (I also have their Kevin of Steel!) Great bikes. they make you WANT to do epic adventures 🥰 Curve Cycling
data.author: Megan Haren

data.text: Love my Lynskey fleet
data.author: Scott Barber
